Dear Shawn M Knodel:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
05/29/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing all the following:
• (b) Verification that the foster parent is
willing to accept the foster child.
Two of the three borrowed home records reviewed did not include adequate
documentation the foster parent was willing to accept the foster child for placement.
Typically, the agency has a standard form to document compliance with this rule,
but it was not able to be located.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing all the following:
• (c) The initial evaluation and current
reevaluation.
One of the three borrowed home records reviewed did not include copies of initial
and subsequent foster home evaluations as required by this rule.
2

CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing all the following:
• (e) Verification of all children currently
placed in the home.
One of the three borrowed home records reviewed did not include verification of the
children currently placed in the home.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing all the following:
• (f) Documentation that the foster parent has
received orientation to the policies of the
borrowing agency.
Two of the three borrowed home records reviewed did not contain adequate
documentation to determine the foster parents received orientation to the related
policies and procedures of the borrowing agency.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing all the following:
• (g) A copy of the foster parent /agency
agreement signed by the foster parent and
the borrowing agency.
Two of the three borrowed foster home records reviewed did not include a copy of a
Foster Parent/Agency Agreement signed between the foster parents and the
borrowing agency.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
3

• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing all the following:
• (a) Approval from the certifying agency
authorizing the placement of a child in the
home.
One of the three borrowed home records reviewed did not include adequate
documentation there was approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of the foster child.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
• (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
• (a) Face-to-face contact between the social
service worker and the youth in
independent living at least once each
month at a youth's place of residence.
One of the six independent living youth records reviewed did not indicate the social
service worker visited the youth in the independent living placement in September
2024.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record
• (3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement
in independent living and updated at least once
every 90 calendar days:
• (o) Service plans as required in R
400.12419 and R 400.12420. If the youth
has biological children, the service plan
must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time
with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or
appropriate.
One of the six independent living youth records reviewed included updated service
plans that were not completed within the time frame required by this rule.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 6 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency Renewal inspection was completed on 4/5/24 and the CAP was
approved on 4/25/24. The agency was cited for 5 violations, 1 of which was a
policy requirement that is no longer being audited. There were no repeat violations
identified as a part of this interim evaluation. Previous CAP was successful as
evidence by lack of repeat violations this year.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001349 was completed on 6/30/24 and the CAP
was approved on 9/9/24. The agency was found in non-compliance as the agency
did not provide adequate safety planning and supervision of a youth that reported
self-harming behaviors. The agency’s CAP included retraining staff, review of the
specific investigation with staff and having monthly team meetings to review the
correction action plan requirements. The agency has complied with the CAP
action steps and no further concerns have been noted.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000242 was completed on 1/29/25 and the CAP
was approved on 2/12/25. The agency was found in non-compliance as the
agency independent living home was not in clean and safe repair as there was
mold in the water. The agency’s CAP included repair of piping, testing for mold
and yeast for six months, and quarterly water test be completed. The agency has
complied with the CAP action steps and no further concerns have been noted.
5

Special Investigation 2025SIC0000239 was completed on 3/13/25 and the CAP
was approved on 4/3/25. The agency was found in non-compliance as a staff
member had an inappropriate sexual conversation with a youth. The agency’s
CAP included termination of staff, sexual harassment training for staff, and
increase boundary discussions during team meetings. The agency CAP is
currently monitored for compliance.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000131 was completed on 2/12/25 and the CAP
was approved on 3/25/25. The agency was found in non-compliance as the
agency has a policy that stated staff could restrain youth which is not allowed. The
agency’s CAP included updating policy, and the policy will be reviewed with staff.
The agency CAP is currently monitored for compliance.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000382 was completed on 4/16/25 and the CAP
was approved on 5/05/2025. The agency was found in non-compliance as a staff
used inappropriate language and threaten a youth. The agency’s CAP included
updating policy, and the policy will be reviewed with staff. The agency CAP is
currently monitored for compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
I reviewed the Chief Administrator Assessment. The Corrective Action Plans
submitted and approved were reviewed along with the action steps associated
with developing compliance for the areas identified in noncompliance. The
unusual amount of staff turnover over the past year was identified as a barrier in
achieving compliance with the areas identified in the CAP. Progress was noted
along with a commitment to continue the implementation of the CAP and the
associated action steps.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff Interviews
Child Welfare Staff participated in entrance and exit conferences. Staff interviews
reported an unusual amount of staff turnover during the past year in both the
administrative and direct services areas. Despite the turnover there was not any
immediate area of concern identified.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and independent living services. All files were
stored securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety concern identified.
6

Safety Alert #1: One home needed a smoke detector.
Resolution: The family installed the required smoke detector. Compliance was
confirmed by pictures and a home visit.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
